Title.evidence: Early Endovenous Ablation for Venous Leg Ulcers: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised 1:1 to early intervention or deferred intervention

Participants.evidence: 450 participants with venous leg ulcers of less than 6 months' duration and superficial venous reflux

Intervention.evidence: early intervention (compression therapy and endovenous ablation within 2 weeks) or deferred intervention (compression therapy with deferred ablation)

Objective.evidence: assessed the clinical and cost-effectiveness of early endovenous ablation of superficial venous reflux in patients with venous leg ulceration

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was time to first ulcer recurrence, measured over a median follow-up of 1286 days

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation used permuted blocks, and allocation was not concealed

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to surgeons, participants, or follow-up assessors

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 450 participants, 224 were randomised to early intervention and 226 to deferred intervention

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 426 participants whose ulcers healed, using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference in time to first ulcer recurrence was observed (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.57-1.17; P = .28)

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported

Funding.evidence: Funding: UK National Institute for Health Research
